Package br.fml.eti.machinegun

Despite the MachineGun is the main class, you can only obtain a machine gun through an Army.

See:
          Description

Interface Summary
Capsule<T> A Capsule is a way to keep the "bullet" (data) intact through the way to the target.
DirtyWork<T> Someone has to do the dirty work.
 

Class Summary
Army Produces machine guns.
MachineGun<T> A "machine gun" avoid stopping the main flow when expensive things is needed, like I/O operations.
Mission<BulletType> To start a new mission, see Army.startNewMission(java.lang.String, java.lang.String, br.fml.eti.behavior.Factory>, br.fml.eti.machinegun.Capsule, int, int, int).
Target<T> A Target groups all the information needed to a bullet (data) reaches your right destination (be processed in the right way).
 

Exception Summary
UnregisteredMissionException See MachineGun.fire(T).
WrongCapsuleException When it was not possible to convert a byte array into the original data or vice-versa.
 

Package br.fml.eti.machinegun Description

Despite the MachineGun is the main class, you can only obtain a machine gun through an Army. This package is a collection of classes to help you do heavy operations in an asynchronous way.

The main idea of the machine-gun project is soften a serial data processing through persisted embedded queues, specially if this processing take some time that the main execution flow cannot wait for.

It is useful, e.g., if you have to persist a lot of new data into a (relative slow) database. You don't want to block your whole main flow to wait this turtle. And you cannot just start a thread to do this, because: 1. your RAM memory will get full quickly. 2. if your PC lost the power or your system go down for any weird reason, you are in trouble. So, let put the logical processing into a persisted queue and process i t as soon as possible, making everything softer.

First, a MachineGun will put everything in an (limited) internal buffer. After, some consumers will put it in an internal persisted queue to finally, others consumers to execute the expensive operation.

Everything (like current operation and time slices) can be externally monitored through an interface called ArmyAudit.
